title: Science can answer moral questions - Sam Harris

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the relationship between science and human values?

options.label: A
options.text: Science has no opinion on human values, and values are unrelated to facts.

options.label: B
options.text: Science can help us understand human values, but it cannot tell us what we ought to value.

options.label: C
options.text: Science and human values are separate spheres that cannot be connected.

options.label: D
options.text: Science is the only source of human values.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker arguing about the concept of morality?

options.label: A
options.text: That morality is relative and subjective.

options.label: B
options.text: That morality is based on cultural and personal opinions.

options.label: C
options.text: That morality is a fact that can be understood and studied scientifically.

options.label: D
options.text: That morality is a matter of personal taste.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the relationship between facts and values?

options.label: A
options.text: Facts and values are separate and unrelated.

options.label: B
options.text: Facts can inform our values, but they do not determine them.

options.label: C
options.text: Facts are a type of value that can be studied and understood scientifically.

options.label: D
options.text: Values are a type of fact that can be studied and understood scientifically.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's view on the concept of moral progress?

options.label: A
options.text: That moral progress is impossible and that all cultures are equally valid.

options.label: B
options.text: That moral progress is possible, but it is a matter of personal opinion.

options.label: C
options.text: That moral progress is possible and that it can be achieved through the study of human values and facts.

options.label: D
options.text: That moral progress is not necessary and that all cultures are equally valid.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the importance of understanding human well-being?

options.label: A
options.text: It is not important and that all cultures are equally valid.

options.label: B
options.text: It is important, but it is a matter of personal opinion.

options.label: C
options.text: It is important and that it can be achieved through the study of human values and facts.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not possible to understand human well-being and that all cultures are equally valid.

options.label: D
